feed.title: SAP Community - SAP Business Technology Platform
feed.subtitle: SAP Business Technology Platform Q&A in SAP Community

entry.title: SAP Datasphere - How to handle ERP connection mapping (DIX ‚Üí QIX) when transporting Replication Flow
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I‚Äôm working on a transport scenario for SAP Datasphere using SAP Cloud Transport Management (CTMS) between two BTP subaccounts:

  • DEV subaccount ‚Üí contains SAP Datasphere connected to ERP DEV system (connection name: DIX)

  • QAS subaccount ‚Üí contains SAP Datasphere connected to ERP QAS system (connection name: QIX)

In the DEV environment, I created a Replication Flow that extracts data from an ABAP CDS View in ERP DEV via the connection DIX.

When I export this Replication Flow from Datasphere DEV (using CTMS), the exported package seems to include the connection reference as well.
However, when I import the same transport package into the Datasphere QAS environment, I‚Äôm not sure how Datasphere handles the source connection ‚Äî because in QAS, the ERP connection should point to QIX (ERP QAS), not DIX (ERP DEV).
My questions:

  1. Does SAP Datasphere automatically detect and remap the connection from DIX ‚Üí QIX during import?
    (I assume no ‚Äî since Datasphere does not have a logical system mapping concept like SAP BW.)

  2. If not, is there any connection mapping mechanism similar to BDLS (logical system mapping) in SAP BW?

  3. Is it possible to maintain a mapping configuration file (e.g., JSON) for connection replacement during import via CTMS?

  4. What is the best practice for naming and managing ERP connections across DEV / QAS / PROD systems to ensure smooth transports?

Any documentation link or official guidance on connection mapping for Replication Flows in Datasphere would be highly appreciated.

Thank you!

entry.title: How can I replicate the passwords defined in SAP IAS to my destination system
entry.content:
I'm using IAS as the source and S4HANA on-premise as the target, and I've already implemented user replication.

However, I'm having a problem. I want to use the same password that each user has defined in SAP IAS so they can log into the S4HANA system, but I haven't been able to. The only thing I see in the transformations default code indicates that a random password is created with certain requirements, such as character count, uppercase and lowercase letters, etc.

 

Does anyone know if this is possible?

If it is, could you guide me on the configuration I should change?

entry.title: What architectural frameworks, MLOps practices, or data orchestration tools would you recommend?
entry.content:
Q: What architectural frameworks, MLOps practices, or data orchestration tools would you recommend to ensure continuous learning, low-latency predictions, and trustworthy analytics outputs in production environments?

Our organization is currently implementing enterprise-level Data and AI solutions to enhance predictive analytics and automate business intelligence processes. However, we‚Äôre facing several technical obstacles during the integration phase. Specifically, we‚Äôre struggling to design a robust data pipeline that can efficiently handle large-scale, heterogeneous data sources ‚Äî including IoT streams, ERP systems, and cloud databases ‚Äî while maintaining data quality, lineage, and governance. Additionally, our AI models trained on historical data aren‚Äôt performing well in real-time scenarios due to inconsistent feature updates and model drift. We‚Äôve been experimenting with tools like Azure Machine Learning, Power BI, and Databricks, but syncing these components into a seamless Data and AI solutions architecture has proven difficult. Has anyone here tackled similar challenges in building a scalable, automated AI-driven ecosystem?

entry.title: Unable to get Authorized object
entry.content:
Hi, 
I am using SAP B1.Can someone please help me with this, When I am trying to getting the session id from the Postman its giving me success response 



But when I am trying to do same thing with .net code its throwing the error 


Here is my code snippet as well

string endpoint = $"{baseURL.TrimEnd('/')}/{version.Trim('/')}/Login";

var payload = new
{
CompanyDB = "SBODemoUS",
UserName = "manager",
Password = "xxxxxxx"
};

string jsonContent = JsonConvert.SerializeObject(payload);
var handler = new HttpClientHandler
{
ServerCertificateCustomValidationCallback = (message, cert, chain, errors) => true
};

var httpclient = new HttpClient(handler);
var content = new StringContent(jsonContent, null, "application/json");
var response = await httpclient.PostAsync(endpoint, content);
if (!response.IsSuccessStatusCode)
{
var responseContent = await response.Content.ReadAsStringAsync();
}


I also overserved that when I am trying to run the same code from .net core its working but when I am trying with .net 4.7 its throwing error.

entry.title: Plan for migration of interfaces to SAP Cloud Integration(Int. Suite)
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

We are in to aumotive industry,, This is regarding our ongoing plan to replace all the existing PO/PI instances with the shared SAP Cloud Integration(Int. Suite). As you know, we currently have Team A, Team B, Team C, , each using their own SAP PO/PI system, SAP backends, and individual integration teams. Say for example team A ; team B ;; team C ;;   Also each team has its distinct partner system or common partner system &  common plants between each two teams.  I have the following questions in terms of better architecture, implementation, design, stability, future proof, and operations etc.,

(i) Would it be beneficial for each team to migrate their ICOs to their own Pipeline concept iFlows.

(ii) Should we migrate interfaces system by system (or) plant by plant in a phased manner.

(iii) Standardization and Consistency, Operational Efficiency, Resource Management and Faster Migration (Long-Term), better integration patterns and reducing the complexity etc.

Regards,

Ramu.

entry.title: Routes quota exceeded error on new BTP trial account
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I created a new BTP trial account in region US East (VA) - AWS. When i tried to deploy my app to the cloud foundry env i got the following error : Controller operation failed: 422 Unprocessable Entity: CF-UnprocessableEntity(10008): Routes quota exceeded for organization '********trial'
I checked the entitlements and the Cloud Foundry environment is already there. Also tried adding a space quota and assigning it to my dev space, but that didn't help either.

‚ÄÉAny ideas on how to resolve this issue ?

entry.title: API Execution Failed When Trying to Use ‚ÄúTry Out‚Äù Feature in SAP Cloud Integration API on BTP Trial
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I recently ran into an issue while experimenting with SAP Cloud Integration on my SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) Trial Account, and I wanted to share my experience here in case anyone else has faced something similar‚Äîor if someone can point me in the right direction.

Scenario

As part of my learning journey in SAP Integration Suite, I created an Integration Flow (iFlow) in Cloud Integration (CPI) and successfully deployed it.

Then, I exposed the iFlow as an API through the API Management capability of BTP so that I could access it externally via a REST API call.

Everything went smoothly until I tried to test the API using the ‚ÄúTry Out‚Äù feature from SAP API Business Hub.

Steps Followed

  1. Logged in to my SAP BTP Trial account.

  2. Opened Integration Suite ‚Üí Cloud Integration.

  3. Created and deployed an iFlow that returns some sample data.

  4. Exposed the iFlow as an API Proxy using API Management ‚Üí Design ‚Üí API Proxies.

  5. Opened the Cloud Integration API package on SAP API Business Hub.

  6. Clicked ‚ÄúTry Out‚Äù to test one of the APIs (for example, /MessageProcessingLogs).

  7. Given the clientid and clientsecret from instance default_it-rt_integration-flow and also I tried with my BTP sign inuser id and password and it shows API execution failed. Please try again.

    Issue Facing

    When I clicked Execute, the system returned the following message:

    API execution failed. Please try again.

    No additional error details were displayed in the response window, and the API call did not reach my iFlow endpoint.

    Troubleshooting Attempted

    Here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve tried so far:

    • Verified that the iFlow is deployed and active.

    • Checked the runtime URL from the Monitor ‚Üí Manage Integration Content page.

    • Verified that my trial tenant is active and not in suspended state.

    • Checked API Business Hub ‚ÄúTry Out‚Äù feature for other packages ‚Äî same issue occurs, which might indicate an environment limitation.

      My Understanding So Far

      It seems that the ‚ÄúTry Out‚Äù feature on SAP API Business Hub might not support BTP Trial environments for certain APIs, especially those requiring authenticated connections to Cloud Integration runtime.

      In a productive BTP setup (non-trial), the ‚ÄúTry Out‚Äù function usually works fine when proper credentials and destinations are configured.

      Request for Help

      Has anyone successfully used the Cloud Integration API ‚ÄúTry Out‚Äù feature with a Trial account?
      If so, could you please share:

      • Any specific configuration or destination settings needed for trial accounts

      • Whether OAuth token-based authentication is mandatory

      • Or if this limitation is by design for BTP Trial users

        Conclusion

        I‚Äôm learning a lot about SAP Integration Suite and the API Management capabilities on BTP.
        Even though I‚Äôve hit this roadblock, it‚Äôs been a great opportunity to understand how authentication and API exposure work behind the scenes in the SAP ecosystem.

        Would love to hear from the community if anyone has faced and resolved this issue! üôå

entry.title: SAP Service & Asset Manager 2505 ‚Äì Document Duplication After Sync
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I am facing an issue in SAP Service & Asset Manager (SSAM) 2505 related to document attachments. This happens in both the Work Order Details screen and the Work Order Operation Details screen.

Issue Description:
In the Documents section, when I add a photo (or any other document), the upload works correctly. After adding the document, I can edit it and save it without any issue.

However, once I perform a Sync, something unexpected happens:

The document successfully appears in the backend  ‚Üí so the upload is working.

The sync completes without errors.

But after the sync, the same document appears duplicated in the mobile app.

The duplicated document shows the sync icon (sync wheel indicator) on the left side, even though the original document is already synced. attached image file (Attached image: img.jpg)

After syncing, a single duplicate of the document appears ‚Äî subsequent syncs do not create additional duplicates.

Please note that -> I am using a created Android client with the following version:
"AppVersion": "2505.0.1"

Has anyone experienced this duplication behavior in SSAM 2505?
Is there any known fix, metadata adjustment, or rule modification required to prevent from this issue?

Any guidance would be greatly appreciated.

Best Regards

Divan Wellalage

entry.title: Feasibility check on data migration approach from Pega Cloud to SAP BTP
entry.content:
Dear SAP Experts,

We are currently defining the data layer modernization strategy for a client planning to rebuild their existing Pega-based case management and workflow solution on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP). 

The main ask from Client is if SAP BTP offers the same or better functionality to rebuild a Workflow based Application with all the specification and implementation the client currently has available for the Pega-based application running on ASPIRE Version.

Since the underlying PostgreSQL database in Pega is tightly coupled with the Pega application and not directly accessible externally, we are proposing a staged extraction and migration approach using the Pega BIX tool.

Below is the detailed end-to-end data flow and migration approach we would like SAP to validate for compliance and supportability within the BTP ecosystem:

Proposed Data Flow

  1. Source System (Pega Application):

    • Data to be extracted using Pega BIX tool in Database Schema output format.

    • Extracted data stored in Pega Cloud File Storage, as per standard Pega BIX process.

  2. Staging Database Setup:

    • Files from Pega Cloud File Storage transferred securely (via SFTP or equivalent) to a Staging PostgreSQL Database, deployed within the same hyperscaler region where SAP BTP is hosted (e.g., AWS, Azure, or GCP).

    • This staging environment will be used for initial validation, transformation, and reconciliation of extracted data.

  3. Migration to SAP BTP Data Layer:

    • Data from the Staging PostgreSQL DB will be migrated to the SAP BTP Hyperscaler Managed PostgreSQL service using native PostgreSQL utilities such as pg_dump, pg_restore, or pg_basebackup alongside psql (for data validation)

    • Target PostgreSQL DB in SAP BTP will act as the primary persistence layer for new SAP Build Process Automation (BPA) and SAP Build Apps-based workflow applications with CAP service as API interfaces to that persistency layer.

Clarification Needed

Can anyone please validate on the following points:

  1. Whether this external data ingestion and migration pattern (Pega underlying PostgreSQL DB ‚Üí Pega BIX tool ‚Üí Staging PostgreSQL DB ‚Üí Hyperscaler PostgreSQL in SAP BTP) is technically compliant and supported within SAP BTP guidelines.

  2. Whether any additional services such as SAP Data Intelligence, SAP Integration Suite, or SAP Data Provisioning Agent for better orchestration or governance in this migration pattern is required or only using PostgreSQL native utilities like pg_dump/pg_restore/psql is enough. 

BR,

Som

#Pega #SAPBTP #MigrateFromPegaToSAPBTP #HyperscalerPostgreSQLOption

entry.title: How to access failed messages from AEM Dead Message queue (DMQ) in Cloud Integration?
entry.content:
I have a scenario where i am connecting iFlow in CI to AEM via the AdvancedEventMesh adapter and as per the current design, i need to retry a failed message a few times (intermittent connectivity issue) before moving the message to a Dead message queue (DMQ) in AEM. My question here is 

  1.  How do i access the message from DMQ later and move it to the original queue for my iFlow to reprocess the message towards the target system?
  2. Should I create a separate queue for DMQ in the Broker manager?
  3. How do i make sure the retry process doesn't go on a loop if the message i retry from the DMQ doesn't get delivered to the target?

entry.title: Deployment Fails Due to Limited Dev Space in SAP BTP Cloud Foundry ‚Äì How to Resolve?
entry.content:
Hi Team!

I am working in SAP BTP Cloud Foundry, and my application deployment is failing because the dev space quota is getting exhausted (memory, disk, or service instance limits). The error indicates that the Cloud Foundry space does not have enough available resources to complete the deployment.

Could you please guide me on:

  1. How to check the current resource usage (memory, disk, app instances, service instances) for my Cloud Foundry org/space?

  2. What steps I can take to free up space (e.g., deleting old apps or services, clearing buildpacks, etc.)?

  3. Whether it is possible to request or increase quota for the Cloud Foundry dev space, and how to do that?

  4. Any best practices to avoid running into resource limitations during deployment?

Any help or suggestions would be greatly appreciated.
Thanks!

entry.title: How to Consume SCIM 2.0 API from SAPUI5 Application in SAP Business Application Studio?
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I am trying to integrate a SCIM 2.0 API (Users endpoint) into an existing SAPUI5 application running in SAP Business Application Studio. I have already configured an HTTP destination in my BTP subaccount with Basic Authentication.
However, when I try to consume this destination from the SAPUI5 app during local preview (using Fiori Tools), I repeatedly get the error: ‚Äúservice-destination: missing required property: type‚Äù
The BAS preview runtime does not seem to recognize or bind the destination.
I also attempted to define the destination inside xs-app.json and route /scim/ paths to the destination, but BAS still does not pick it up. Since this is a standalone SAPUI5 application, there is no runConfigurations folder or approuter module, just an xs-app.json.
Additionally, direct AJAX calls to the SCIM endpoint fail due to CORS and server-side authentication restrictions.

My question is:
Is there any supported approach to call SCIM 2.0 APIs directly from a SAPUI5 application in BAS?
If there is a way to make the destination available during local preview for standalone SAPUI5 apps, please guide me on the correct configuration.
Any insights, best practices, or examples would be greatly appreciated.
#SCIM #SCIMAPI #SAPUI5

entry.title: How are you all handling cross system workflow automation between SAP and other apps?
entry.content:
I have been exploring ways to simplify AI driven workflows that span across SAP and a bunch of non SAP apps. The challenge I keep running into is that the data lives in too many places, which makes it tough to create smooth AI workflows without constant manual effort or heavy custom development.

Curious to know how others here are solving this.
Are you using custom BTP apps, iPaaS tools, or something else entirely?
Have you found an approach that works well for automating workflows that need both SAP data and external system data in real time?

Looking to learn what has worked well for your teams and what pitfalls to avoid.

entry.title: @cap-js/mcp-server - Practical guide to get value on day on
entry.content:
Give your coding assistant instant, project‚Äëaware knowledge of your CAP model and docs. With @cap-js/mcp-server, the assistant can look up entities, services, fields, and HTTP endpoints from your compiled CDS model and cross‚Äëcheck official CAP docs, so it proposes the right code and changes in your editor.

Here's where I found this and would like to share with community - https://github.com/cap-js/mcp-server

  • Package: @cap-js/mcp-server
  • Command: cds-mcp
  • Tools: search_model (compiled CDS/CSN), search_docs (local CAP docs embeddings)
  • Works with MCP‚Äëcapable assistants in VS Code and other IDEs (e.g., Cline, Copilot Agent Mode, opencode)

Here‚Äôs the short version - just follow these 3 step

  1. Configure your IDE agent to start the server via npx:
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "cds-mcp": {
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["-y", "@cap-js/mcp-server"],
      "env": {}
    }
  }
}
  1. Add these rules to AGENTS.md so the assistant always uses the server correctly:
- You MUST search for CDS definitions, like entities, fields and services (which include HTTP endpoints) with cds-mcp, only if it fails you MAY read *.cds files in the project.
- You MUST search for CAP docs with cds-mcp EVERY TIME you create, modify CDS models or when using APIs or the `cds` CLI from CAP. Do NOT propose, suggest or make any changes without first checking it.
  1. Optional CLI smoke test:
npm i -g @cap-js/mcp-server
cds-mcp search_model . Books entity
cds-mcp search_docs "how to add columns to a select statement in CAP Node.js" 1

Why you‚Äôll love it

  • Stop guessing: Fuzzy‚Äësearch your compiled model for entities, services, elements, annotations, and endpoints.
  • Fewer mistakes: Suggestions are grounded in your actual model and verified against official CAP docs.
  • All local: Fast and private, perfect for day‚Äëto‚Äëday development.

IDE setup

VS Code - Cline extension

Settings example:

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "cds-mcp": {
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["-y", "@cap-js/mcp-server"],
      "env": {}
    }
  }
}

VS Code - GitHub Copilot Agent Mode (global mcp.json)

{
  "servers": {
    "cds-mcp": {
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["-y", "@cap-js/mcp-server"],
      "env": {},
      "type": "stdio"
    },
    "inputs": []
  }
}

opencode

{
  "mcp": {
    "cds-mcp": {
      "type": "local",
      "command": ["npx", "-y", "@cap-js/mcp-server"],
      "enabled": true
    }
  }
}

Tip: Keep the server name ‚Äúcds-mcp‚Äù in both your config and prompts so your assistant reliably calls it.

How to use it in your editor

Think ‚Äúdiscover first, then change.‚Äù Ask your assistant to:

  • Discover model and endpoints

    • ‚ÄúUse cds‚Äëmcp search_model to list all services and their HTTP endpoints. Then list entities with primary keys.‚Äù

  • Write a correct SELECT with expand

    • ‚ÄúCall cds‚Äëmcp search_model for Books and its associations. Then, after checking CAP Node.js SELECT expand syntax via cds‚Äëmcp search_docs, propose a handler that returns Books.title, Books.stock and expands auther.name.‚Äù

  • Generate precise OData URLs

    • ‚ÄúFind the service and endpoint for Books via search_model, then give me an OData V4 URL with $select=title,stock and $expand=author($select=name) plus a curl example.‚Äù

  • Safely change CDS/annotations

    • ‚ÄúShow docs for @Common.Label using cds‚Äëmcp search_docs. Using search_model for Books, propose a minimal diff adding labels for title and stock. Include file paths.‚Äù

  • Plan a refactor

    • ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre renaming Author to Writer. With cds‚Äëmcp search_model, list affected entities, associations, services, and endpoints; propose a step‚Äëby‚Äëstep PR plan.‚Äù

  • Implement an action/handler

    • ‚ÄúFind docs on defining and implementing a custom action in Node.js via cds‚Äëmcp search_docs. Then sketch a minimal handler in srv/<service>.js with imports and input validation.‚Äù

Best practice: Ask the assistant to paste the search_model and search_docs results that justify any change.

CLI usage (optional but handy)

Install globally to test from your terminal:

npm i -g @cap-js/mcp-server
  • Search your compiled model:
cds-mcp search_model . Books entity
  • Search CAP documentation:
cds-mcp search_docs "how to add columns to a select statement in CAP Node.js" 1

Once the CLI works, your IDE agent can invoke the same tools automatically.

What the tools return

  • search_model

    • Names and kinds (entity, service, etc.)
    • Elements and annotations
    • File locations
    • HTTP endpoints where services are exposed

  • search_docs

    • The most relevant CAP documentation snippets for your query, based on local embeddings

Use both together: discover exact names/paths with search_model, confirm syntax and best practices with search_docs, then apply small, reviewable changes.

Tips for getting the most value

  • Start every task with search_model to avoid typos and stale assumptions.
  • Require docs‚Äëbacked edits: have the assistant run search_docs before proposing code.
  • Keep edits atomic: one focused change at a time, with file paths and minimal diffs.
  • Monorepo? Tell the assistant the CAP project folder to search.

Support and contribution

  • Issues and feature requests: https://github.com/cap-js/mcp-server/issues
  • Security policy: https://github.com/cap-js/mcp-server/security/policy
  • Code of Conduct: https://github.com/cap-js/.github/blob/main/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md
  • License and REUSE info: see LICENSE and https://api.reuse.software/info/github.com/cap-js/mcp-server

Now action - 

  • Add the MCP config, paste the two rules into AGENTS.md, and ask your assistant:
    ‚ÄúDiscover all entities, keys, and endpoints with cds‚Äëmcp search_model, verify the Node.js SELECT docs with cds‚Äëmcp search_docs, then propose a minimal handler change for Books.‚Äù

    SAP Business Technology Platform  SAP Business AI SAP Cloud Application Programming Model

entry.title: Mastering GitOps with Argo CD: A Complete Guide to Declarative Kubernetes Deployments
entry.content:
Introduction

In the world of cloud-native engineering, agility and reliability often clash. Developers need speed; operators need control. Traditional CI/CD pipelines, though effective, rely heavily on manual approvals, ad-hoc scripting, and push-based workflows ‚Äî all prone to configuration drift and human error.

GitOps changes the game by using Git as the single source of truth for both infrastructure and application configurations. With Argo CD, a Kubernetes-native continuous delivery controller, you can automate deployments, enforce configuration consistency, and self-heal your clusters ‚Äî all through declarative manifests stored in Git.

This article provides an end-to-end, production-ready walkthrough of how to design, deploy, and operate Kubernetes workloads using Argo CD and GitOps principles ‚Äî including advanced features such as multi-environment automation, Helm integration, sync policies, and best practices for scale.

What Is GitOps?

GitOps is a modern methodology for managing and operating cloud-native infrastructure and applications using Git as the single source of truth. It shifts the deployment paradigm from manual, imperative commands (like kubectl apply) to a declarative, automated workflow, where the desired state of your system is stored and versioned in Git.

Key principles of GitOps include:

1. Git as the Source of Truth

  • All infrastructure and application configurations are defined declaratively in Git.
  • Git commits represent the desired system state, enabling versioning, traceability, and auditability.

2. Pull-Based Automation

  • A GitOps operator continuously monitors Git for changes and reconciles the live system with the desired state.
  • Any drift between Git and the running environment is detected and corrected automatically.

3. Automated Rollbacks and Auditing

  • Since every change is a Git commit, rolling back to a previous state is as simple as reverting a commit.
  • All actions are auditable, providing a clear history of changes and deployments.

In essence: With GitOps, you declare what you want, commit it to Git, and let automation ensure that your cluster matches that desired state ‚Äî reliably, securely, and consistently.

It combines the benefits of version control, CI/CD, and automation into a single, streamlined approach for managing modern cloud-native applications.

Why Choose Argo CD?

Argo CD is a Kubernetes-native continuous delivery tool that fully implements GitOps principles, making it an ideal choice for teams seeking automation, reliability, and scalability. Here‚Äôs why Argo CD stands out:

1. Continuous Synchronization

  • Automatically monitors Git repositories and synchronizes changes to Kubernetes clusters.
  • Ensures the live state always matches the desired state defined in Git.

2. Real-Time Drift Detection and Self-Healing

  • Detects any manual changes or configuration drift in the cluster.
  • Automatically corrects deviations to maintain consistency.

3. Multi-Cluster and Multi-Environment Support

  • Manage deployments across multiple clusters and environments from a single Argo CD instance.
  • Supports environment overlays for dev, staging, and production setups.

4. Application Visualization and Health Monitoring

  • Provides a UI and CLI to visualize application status, dependencies, and health.
  • Supports monitoring health states like Healthy, Progressing, Degraded, or Suspended.

5. Support for Multiple Deployment Tools

  • Deploy raw YAML, Helm charts, Kustomize overlays, or Jsonnet configurations.
  • Flexible enough to handle simple apps or complex, multi-service systems.

6. Secure and Role-Based Access

  • Built-in RBAC for controlling access to applications, clusters, and repositories.
  • Ensures secure operations in collaborative, multi-team environments.

In short: Argo CD transforms Git commits into the live state of your Kubernetes clusters ‚Äî consistently, automatically, and safely ‚Äî making it a trusted GitOps engine for modern cloud-native deployments.

Step 1: Setting Up Argo CD

Let‚Äôs deploy Argo CD in a Kubernetes cluster.

Prerequisites

  • A Kubernetes cluster (Minikube, Kind, AKS, EKS, or GKE)
  • kubectl installed and configured
  • A GitHub or GitLab repository for your manifests

Installing Commands

kubectl create namespace argocd
kubectl apply -n argocd \
  -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/argoproj/argo-cd/stable/manifests/install.yaml

Once deployed, Argo CD runs several components:

  • argocd-server ‚Äì exposes the UI, API, and CLI
  • argocd-repo-server ‚Äì interacts with Git repositories
  • argocd-application-controller ‚Äì reconciles application states
  • argocd-dex-server ‚Äì handles authentication
  • argocd-redis ‚Äì caching and internal coordination

Accessing the UI

kubectl port-forward svc/argocd-server -n argocd 8080:443

Then open https://localhost:8080.

Retrieve the admin password:

kubectl -n argocd get secret argocd-initial-admin-secret \
  -o jsonpath="{.data.password}" | base64 -d

 

Step 2: Connecting a Git Repository

In the Argo CD UI:
Settings ‚Üí Repositories ‚Üí Connect Repo ‚Üí Add Git URL + Credentials.

Alternatively, via CLI:

argocd repo add https://github.com/myorg/gitops-manifests.git \
  --username <user> --password <token>

Argo CD now watches this repository and continuously scans it for configuration changes.

Step 3: Creating and Deploying Applications

Applications are the core Argo CD resources. They define what to deploy, where, and how.

Sample Application Definition

apiVersion: argoproj.io/v1alpha1
kind: Application
metadata:
  name: nginx-demo
  namespace: argocd
spec:
  project: default
  source:
    repoURL: https://github.com/myorg/gitops-manifests.git
    path: apps/nginx
    targetRevision: main
  destination:
    server: https://kubernetes.default.svc
    namespace: demo
  syncPolicy:
    automated:
      prune: true
      selfHeal: true
    syncOptions:
      - CreateNamespace=true

Apply this:

kubectl apply -f nginx-application.yaml

Argo CD fetches the manifests, applies them to the cluster, and keeps them in sync with Git automatically.

 

Step 4: Understanding Deployment Strategies

Argo CD supports multiple deployment approaches:

1. Plain YAML

Store raw manifests under version control ‚Äî simplest setup but less flexible.

2. Helm Charts

Argo CD can deploy Helm charts directly without helm CLI:

source:
  repoURL: https://charts.bitnami.com/bitnami
  chart: nginx
  targetRevision: 13.2.9
  helm:
    values: |
      replicaCount: 3
      service:
        type: ClusterIP

3. Kustomize Overlays

Perfect for multi-environment management:

my-app/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ base/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ deployment.yaml
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ service.yaml
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ kustomization.yaml
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ overlays/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ dev/
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ kustomization.yaml
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ prod/
‚îÇ       ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ kustomization.yaml

4. App-of-Apps Pattern

Used to manage complex systems:

source:
  repoURL: https://github.com/myorg/environment-configs.git
  path: environments/dev

Step 5: Configuration and Synchronization

Sync Policies

Argo CD supports both manual and automated synchronization.

  • Manual Mode: Operators review and trigger syncs manually.
  • Automated Mode: Argo CD applies changes as soon as they are committed to Git.

Example:

syncPolicy:
  automated:
    prune: true
    selfHeal: true
  • Prune removes obsolete resources that no longer exist in Git.
  • SelfHeal ensures that any manual cluster change is automatically reverted.

Sync Options

Argo CD provides advanced sync behaviors:

syncOptions:
  - CreateNamespace=true
  - ApplyOutOfSyncOnly=true
  - PrunePropagationPolicy=foreground

Hooks and Lifecycle Management

You can use Argo CD Resource Hooks to run pre- and post-deployment tasks like database migrations or config validation.

Example:

metadata:
  annotations:
    argocd.argoproj.io/hook: PreSync

Step 6: Observability and Health Monitoring

Argo CD continuously monitors application health using Kubernetes object statuses.

  • Health states: Healthy, Progressing, Degraded, Suspended
  • You can visualize these in the Argo CD UI tree view.

For deeper insights:

  • Metrics: Argo CD exposes Prometheus metrics at /metrics.
  • Dashboards: Integrate with Grafana to visualize sync frequency, drift count, and app health.
  • Notifications: Use Argo CD Notifications for Slack, Teams, or email alerts.

Example config:

triggers:
  - name: on-sync-failure
    condition: app.status.sync.status == 'OutOfSync'
    template: sync-failure

Step 7: Real-World Deployment Workflow

Here‚Äôs a simplified GitOps deployment lifecycle using Argo CD:

  1. Developer updates the manifest or Helm values ‚Üí commits to Git.
  2. CI validates YAML syntax and performs static checks.
  3. Commit is merged to the main branch.
  4. Argo CD detects the commit, fetches the new configuration, and starts reconciliation.
  5. Application is deployed to the cluster.
  6. If any manual drift occurs, Argo CD flags ‚ÄúOutOfSync‚Äù and reverts automatically.
  7. Rollback is as easy as git revert <commit-hash>.

This process guarantees full traceability, automatic rollback, and no manual cluster changes.

Summary: Argo CD as the GitOps Engine

Argo CD brings automation, reliability, and control to Kubernetes deployments through GitOps. It replaces manual, error-prone processes with a declarative, Git-driven model where every change is versioned, traceable, and automatically synchronized to clusters. As environments scale across microservices and multiple clusters, Argo CD ensures consistency, eliminates drift, and enables faster, safer releases. Ultimately, it transforms Git into the operational control plane and provides a predictable, self-healing, and highly observable deployment workflow ‚Äî allowing teams to move quickly without compromising stability.

You define your desired state once, commit to Git, and Argo CD ensures your clusters reflect it ‚Äî continuously and automatically.

This declarative model brings:

  • Auditability: every change is a commit
  • Reliability: drift is self-corrected
  • Scalability: consistent rollout across clusters
  • Security: code-based governance over live clusters

Conclusion

Argo CD is more than a deployment tool ‚Äî it is the operational engine that modernizes how organizations manage Kubernetes at scale. By embracing GitOps, teams shift from fragile, manual, push-based deployments to a fully automated, audit-ready, and self-healing delivery model. Every environment becomes predictable, every rollout becomes traceable, and every configuration becomes reproducible.

As applications grow into distributed microservices and clusters expand across regions or clouds, Argo CD provides the consistency and governance required to keep everything in sync. Its declarative, pull-based architecture eliminates configuration drift, while features like automated sync, app-of-apps orchestration, Helm/Kustomize support, and environment overlays allow teams to design enterprise-grade delivery pipelines with confidence.

In essence, Argo CD turns Git into a control plane for your entire Kubernetes footprint. It bridges the gap between developers and operators by delivering a unified, reliable, and observable deployment workflow.

Adopting GitOps with Argo CD is not just a tooling decision ‚Äî it is an engineering culture upgrade. It empowers teams to deploy faster, recover instantly, collaborate better, and operate with clarity at every stage of the software lifecycle.

In a world where speed and stability are equally critical, Argo CD ensures you never have to choose between the two.

entry.title: How to consume s4 hana public cloud SOAP Outbound Service in CPI for replication
entry.content:
Hii Community,

Can someone help me out how to configure my Sender(S4 Public Cloud) and Consumer(CPI) system to replicate production order data from S4 to MES System through CPI?

I got replication SOAP service from api.sap.com which needs to be activated in SAP. Let me know if someone has done this kind of integration.

I appreciate your attention on question

Regards,

Omkar

entry.title: Cancellation of invoice instead of issuing credit note
entry.content:
Hi, 

I created one invoice for the customer. Customer didn't pay it and said i need to change the rate. so i should have creted one Credit note but instead of creating one credit note i cancelled the invoice and created one new invoice. 

This was mistake from my side. How can i correct it in SAP now? 

Regards

entry.title: SAP HANA Cloud Free Tier shows ‚Äúinstance already exists‚Äù but no instance is visible
entry.content:
We are working in a Pay-As-You-Go SAP BTP partner account and initially created a test SAP CAP application connected to an SAP HANA Cloud database. After deleting this setup to start fresh, we encountered an HDI container‚Äìrelated error while creating a new CAP application. When checking the HANA Cloud section, no database instance was visible, but attempts to create a new HANA Cloud instance consistently fail with an error indicating that an instance already exists. We tried deleting and recreating the HANA Cloud service and even removed the entire subaccount, but the same error persists, suggesting a previously provisioned HANA instance is stuck or orphaned and still consuming quota, blocking further database setup.

Error:  BrokerError, Description: You may only create one SAP HANA Cloud Free Tier instance

Main Issue

While setting up a fresh SAP CAP application, I encountered an HDI container error. When checking SAP HANA Cloud, I noticed that no HANA Cloud instance was visible, even though the system behaves as if one already exists.

What I Tried (and Failed)

  • Create a new SAP HANA Cloud instance
    ‚Üí Failed with an error stating that only one instance is allowed (instance already exists)

  • Delete the HANA Cloud database and recreate everything
    ‚Üí Failed (same error persists)

  • Delete the entire SAP BTP subaccount and recreate everything
    ‚Üí Failed (same error still occurs)

Current Situation

It appears that an existing or orphaned HANA Cloud instance is still consuming quota, even though it is not visible or accessible, which is blocking further database setup and CAP development.

 

I would appreciate any guidance on how to clean up or reset this stuck SAP HANA Cloud instance so that we can proceed with database setup and continue CAP development.
